title: How to Clean a Sink Aerator

steps.headline: Find out if you need to clean the aerator, replace the aerator, or clean some other part.
steps.description: You can figure this out by looking in the manual, calling customer care, or searching online in Google or on the company website.

steps.headline: Plug the drain with something so that the small parts don't fall out.
Now, if you have a pull out head, pull out the spray/water filter part and unscrew the hose from the head.
steps.description: Make sure the hose doesn't retract. Have somebody either hold it or put something heavy on it. People without the pull out heads may skip this step.

steps.headline: Go ahead and find yourself a pair of needle nose pliers.
steps.description: Close them firmly in the little holes (there should be two) on the outer ring of the head.

steps.headline: Give it a counter-clockwise twist, making sure you are holding the head and pliers with a tight grip.
steps.description: After 4-5 full turns, the bottom part should come out.

steps.headline: Get the small parts out as best as possible (don't worry about the parts remaining in the head) and soak them in vinegar.
steps.description: In my case, the aerator was so filthy and grimy I had to use a toothbrush to clean the screen.

steps.headline: Reassemble all the parts.
steps.description: Your water pressure should be restored to its full potential!

text: Find out if you need to clean the aerator, replace the aerator, or clean some other part. You can figure this out by looking in the manual, calling customer care, or searching online in Google or on the company website. Plug the drain with something so that the small parts don't fall out.  Now, if you have a pull out head, pull out the spray/water filter part and unscrew the hose from the head. Make sure the hose doesn't retract. Have somebody either hold it or put something heavy on it. People without the pull out heads may skip this step. Go ahead and find yourself a pair of needle nose pliers. Close them firmly in the little holes (there should be two) on the outer ring of the head. Give it a counter-clockwise twist, making sure you are holding the head and pliers with a tight grip. After 4-5 full turns, the bottom part should come out. Get the small parts out as best as possible (don't worry about the parts remaining in the head) and soak them in vinegar. In my case, the aerator was so filthy and grimy I had to use a toothbrush to clean the screen. Reassemble all the parts. Your water pressure should be restored to its full potential!
